name: Earthmovers Media
bio:
Mack Plovie - Your Favourite Canadian Dirt Enthusiast
• Telling the story of Canadian Mining & Construction
• Listen to our Podcast “In The Dirt”

social_posts.post_text:
Fuelling time for @surewayconstructiongroup big 657E scrapers
—
Fuel and lube truck operators are an under appreciated facet of the jobsite, often starting early and working late to keep iron fuelled, greased, as well as tending to general maintenance
—
For the curious bunch out there, one of these 657’s will sip 1,600 litres of diesel from a fuel tender a little larger than your average pickup tidy tank
—
It’s a full time gig tending to a thirsty fleet of iron

45 cubes of aggregate from Sandhill Materials on its way to help build the infrastructure we all rely on
—
Whether it’s roads, buildings, bridges, highways, railroads, or your personal home. Aggregate products, like those pictured above, are a bigger part of your life than you think
The finest office views I’ve ever come across, yet another perk of working at @mackaybuilds
Standard issue workhorse for Alberta underground utility crews, the 973 tracked loader (traxcavator)
A peek inside the cab of @komatsumining D375a-8 dozer, finally they put finger tip steering in their mining class dozers!

3516B on the dyno at @finningca after a full rebuild. Once thorough dyno testing, a few valve sets, and paint is complete, this engine is headed back into the field to power a 793 haul truck
—
Thanks to certified rebuilds by the professionals at Finning Canada, big diesels like this can live multiple lives, often racking up tens of thousands of hours over their entire lifespan

Back out to Ontario this week for a underground mining project
—
Underground mining has a special place in my heart, it’s a part of the mining industry you’ve likely never heard of or really developed an appreciation for. Not to your own fault, but purely by the fact the mining industry has hidden from the public eye for decades (and continues to do so)
—
With career opportunities plentiful, the industry is restlessly searching for people so it can continue to operate and provide society with the raw ingredients for life
—
I’ll repeat it again again, but the mining industry struggles with being understood and appreciated at a basic level. Hopefully, with cooperation from mining companies, social media can help further the industry narrative in a positive manner

D10R cleaning up the cut in between scrapers. Big dozers often help to tidy things up so scrapers can focus on moving as much earth as possible
—
If you peek the back of the ripper, one will spot a hitch/hook for scrapers to latch onto and be pulled out if the dozers assistance is required

Investing in our infrastructure!
—
In 2015 Parks Canada announced a $95 million dollar investment in Avalanche Mitigation through the Rogers Pass section of the Trans-Canada Hwy
—
@mackaybuilds played a large role in building and maintaining static defence systems that catch or deflect avalanche debris, as well as expanding vehicle holding areas for use during avalanche control/highway closure
—
Keeping Highway 1 open in the winter months is an incredibly import part of the Canadian economy, allowing goods and services to flow un interrupted year round
— 
With infrastructure all over Canada beginning to reveal its age, you can thank contractors like MacKay for building the infrastructure we all desperately rely on

Throwback to @tritontransport hauling what was at the time the first Cat 395 in Western Canada
—
I was enroute to Vancouver and Jared mentioned I may intercept a 395 on its way from Port of Tacoma, WA to Finning Calgary. Just outside of Hope I spotted her in a pullout and nearly had an accident staring in fascination
—
She is 124,500lbs in this configuration (no boom, stick, bucket, counterweight) sitting atop a 3+3+2 Aspen Trailer pulled by a Kenworth W900B
—
Anyone who knows trucking in BC knows the gruelling grade thousands of trucks conquer everyday up the Coquihalla highway (Hwy 5)

Al, truck driver for @solanoresources, proudly pauses in front of his rig
—
As a 3rd generation logger, Al’s been in the business longer than I’ve been alive
—
Being part of the blue collar world, he’s a contributing member to making civilization possible as we know it, hauling timber from deep in the BC mountains to the mills
—
Thanks to people like Al and many others, we all enjoy a better quality of life through BC timber products
This guy is so busted for not wearing his PPE on a demolition site

On a hot summer day, people often dream of having the day off work to frequent the beach. That’s not an issue at Dakota Reclamators (part of @priestlydemolition), they brought the beach to the work place.

@northstarcontracting newest addition to the fleet, a Deere 870G, trenching for over 5.5km of underground utilities including 1200mm storm line, 500mm water line, and 250mm sanitary line on a warehouse expansion project. She’s big, she’s got a selection of buckets & ripper, and she means business.

As the holiday season wraps up, we return to the regular scheduled dirt programming you all come to expect
—
If you were a client, friend, industry connection, sent me an email or DM, were a podcast guest, or said hi along the way in 2022. Thank you, it’s people like you who make the industry a great place

Noboru, now product manager for the Komatsu D375a-8, standing in for scale in front of the very dozer he helped design
—
Noboru was quite excited to see his beloved engineering marvel playing in Alberta dirt. If my memory serves as correct, he helped design the ladder and frame on this big Komatsu
—
It was a fantastic experience watching him see what he and his team worked so hard to make a reality

MINING: stimulating the economy better than our government ever could
—
Creating jobs, tax revenue for local governments, and supplying the raw ingredients for civilization as we know it, Mining is an important and irreplaceable component of the economy
—
While there are more mining companies in Canada than I could sum up in one post, of note, Teck Resources contributions to British Columbia last year alone include:

- $4.6 billion to BC’s GDP
- 12,820 direct and indirect jobs
- $600 million in total government revenues
- $1.4 billion to approximately 900 suppliers in BC
- Responsible for 80% of the GDP in Cranbrook, Fernie, Sparwood regions
- 2 in 5 jobs in the same region thanks to Teck’s activities

Thanks to mining outfits like Teck engaged in responsible development of natural resources, we all enjoy a better quality of life through economic activity it brings

*Photo credit: Teck Resources HVC Operations

@solanoresources loading out a truck load of Interior Douglas Fir onto @peerlesstrailers setup. After Timber is felled, skidded to the lay down, sized and cut by the harvester, a log loader is the final step in getting timber products loaded and shipped to the mill

@mainlandconstructionmaterials big 988K XE cruising into the pit for another scoop of fresh muck (mining lingo for blasted rock)
—
At the time, their primary jaw crusher was close to the pit (just out of frame in the video) so that twin 988’s hauled material from pit to crusher faster and more efficiently than a fleet of haul trucks. As the active pit face advances, so does the primary jaw with addition of conveyors
—
I always enjoy seeing mining companies find their own right way to do it tailored to their application

Another peek at Sureway’s beautiful 777F rigid frames with rubber bottom dump bodies. After many messages and comments, it seems the consensus on these is:
- doesn’t wear as fast as steel/lasts longer in rock
- reduces carry back of material in cold temps
- less shock load when the first bucket hits
- less expensive to replace/repair than steal bed liner

Copper Mountain Mining’s big Komatsu WA1200 on display. Nothing yields an appreciation for mining class equipment like seeing it in person
—
A keen eye will spot XRF sensors mounted in the top of the bucket, these emit X-Rays to scan for copper content that fluoresces when exposed to X-Rays. In short, it’s the mining industries way of using technology to determine sending rock to the mill or to the waste dump. The tech is called “shovel sense”.
On the prowl for timber in the woods of British Columbia @solanoresources

Vinci Construction’s new nine hundred fifty excavator making quick work of frozen Alberta earth. There is over 5 million cubes of earth to move on this project between two Volvo 950’s with a fleet of Cat wiggles and rigid frame trucks

Join me for a tour of the Cat R1700 scooptram cab. The controls resemble that of a large wheel loader with the major difference being you sit sideways in the unit
—
Underground mining equipment is purpose built for the application, LHD or load-haul-dump scooptrams have a visibly lower profile with a uniquely engineered bucket and lifting arc

Ben (@bensuurallik), park cat operator for @sunshinevillage, at the helm of their new PistenBully Park Pro 400
—
Ben started 12 years ago free grooming, winch cat grooming, and today can be found in the terrain park building various features or maintaining the snowboard cross course
—
It’s a pleasure to watch Ben work, a true artist behind the controls with a contagious passion for shaping snow and laying down corduroy
—
He is one of the many who work behind the scenes and quite often through the night to make winter recreation at Sunshine Village possible for the rest of us to enjoy

Whissell Contracting’s 395 swinging in another 12.2m section of 1050mm pipe. Even with a long stick she has some lifting muscle
—
It’s not too often you see this large of machine putting in pipe in the neighbourhood, yet another typical day in Alberta

Alberta’s largest infrastructure project to date, the $744 million Springbank Dam off stream reservoir project (SR1)
—
After devastating floods in 2013 caused an estimated $5 billion in damages to Southern Alberta. The government set out to mitigate future flooding by building an off stream reservoir on the Elbow River
—
The project itself covers 3,700 acres of land and requires a little over 5 million cubes to be moved in a timely fashion for construction of a 3.5km long diversion ditch and 2km long 100ft tall dam 
—
In addition to similar infrastructure on the Bow River, SR1 will allow flood waters to be captured and stored until they can be released back into the Elbow River post flooding event

Another load of BC Interior Douglas Fir Timber on its way to the mill thanks to the folks at @solanoresources
—
After watching a few loads, I would argue loading a logging truck with timber requires more skill and attention to detail than loading a rigid/wiggle with dirt

What the heck is a tailings pond/tailings storage facility?
—
After rock bearing precious metals (ore) is extracted from the open pit and processed through the mill, a waste rock product (tailings) is produced typically in the form of a fine silt/sand
—
This non economic tailings product reports to a tailings storage facility (TSF), essentially a lake created by a man made dam where silt/sand settles out and water is recycled for reuse in the milling process. Tailings are then stored here for the lifespan of the mine
—
At a mining rate of 45,000 tonnes per day (TPD) this particular TSF grows vertically 5m per year and holds 2 million cubes of water!
Back out to visit the awesome folks over at @mainlandconstructionmaterials today, they’ve added a new production wheel loader to the fleet. Can you guess what it is? Stay tuned!

One of Vinci Construction’s D10T ripping and pushing a mixture silt/mud/sandstone to make way for a 24m wide 3.5km long diversion ditch as part of a reservoir project. Apart from draglines, big dozers are one of the more cost effective methods to move large amounts of earth in a jiffy
Twin 657E scrapers gobbling up 88 cubic yards of Alberta dirt in push-pull formation. Dirt spilling over the bowl always stirs up some genuine excitement within me
Big girl on the move @finningca

The visible footprint of mining
—
Many regard the footprint of mining as negative, commenting on tailings facilities, open pits, or general mine infrastructure as “bad” and “destructive to the natural environment”
—
Yet where would be as a civilization without extracting and using natural resources?
—
Unfortunately the bulk of society believes any disturbance to natural environment = bad. When in reality they have been lead completely astray, civilization wouldn’t exist without responsible natural resource extraction like that of modern day Canadian mining
—
How different is the footprint of mining (which is merely a temporary use of the land by method of reclamation) than that of a large city? Solar farm? Landfill? Notable 4 lane highway stretching for miles? 
—
We certainly don’t look down upon those negatively. It’s time we think different about how important mining is in our daily lives

@mainlandconstructionmaterials new Cat 992 wheel loader at their Cox Quarry operations loading 60 tonne 775 haul trucks at 20tonne per pass
—
This machine originally came new from the Netherlands and is sporting a 16.5 cubic yard ESCO rock bucket armoured for the high silica content (70-77%) of Cox Quarry granite 
—
A keen eye will notice no more than 1.5 rotations of the wheel between filling and dumping the bucket, key component of an efficient and productive loading operation

D8T pre-ripping the cut prior to the Volvo 950 digging in. One would be surprised how much difference a few passes to break up the top layer of earth will make when production loading out frozen or compacted material

Weighted rippers on big dozers!
—
Weight is typically added to dozer rippers to balance the tractor, typically when a larger blade is affixed causing the machine to be nose heavy (first photo, D475 with 60 cy3 blade in super dozer configuration)
—
An unbalanced tractor will cause excess wear on undercarriage amongst other less favourable things
—
The other instance where weight is added is for steep slope reclamation work. Weight is added to the rear of the tractor to help gain traction when backing up steep slopes without having to go around for another downhill approach (second photo of a D10)
—
You would be surprised what you can learn with an open mind wandering about job/mine sites. Neat!

Pistenbully’s newest iteration of their Park Pro 400, a dedicated snowcat for terrain parks
—
These cats differ slightly from regular 400 size snowcats by the achievable range of motion the blade and tiller have for shaping terrain park features. Swipe to see what I mean!
—
Other differences include cuttings edges on the side of the blade, forks built into the blade, and a tiller that oscillates about the center for laying down corduroy on convex or concave features 
—
By any means, in the hands of a snow artist like @bensuurallik, it’s an absolute weapon

Volvo’s largest digging in on Calgary’s most notable infrastructure project to date, the Springbank offstream Resevoir (SR1)
—
She is spec’d with a 9’8” ME stick and a 9.25 cube Volvo bucket for loading out 60 ton Cat 773E rigid frames in a jiffy. No one moves dirt like Alberta moves dirt! 
—
Operator credit: @matea.herauf

Throwback to @kidco_constructionltd involvement in the $1.2 billion dollar waterfront development project in Royal Bay, Victoria BC
—
The 135 acre site was was previously an aggregate quarry, now Victoria’s largest development featuring 2,850 homes, condos, and townhomes with retail, commercial, and green space intermixed 
—
Since there are no contractors capable of mass earthworks on Vancouver Island. Kidco transported their iron by road from Calgary AB to Vancouver BC, then barged it all over to Vancouver Island for the project
—
While most of Vancouver Island is pure rock, select areas like Royal Bay are covered with plentiful amounts of dirt, sand, and gravel, summoning 657 scrapers and PC1250’s to recontour the land 
—
Watching Kidco’s PC1250 loading 40 tonne wiggles, now that’s a show I’m buying tickets to see
Where’s Waldo, heavy equipment technician edition. Can you spot the technician? @northamericanconstructiongroup

If you can’t push it, rip it, then push it
—
One of Vinci’s D10T slipping a few feet of steel ripper shank into Alberta rock. Like a knife through chunky peanut butter is the expression that comes to mind

A freshly cut handful of beautiful BC timber on its way to the mill. After timber is felled it is skidded (dragged by a skidder) to the main lay down where a processor then delimbs, sizes, and cuts it for loading onto log trucks and eventually the mill
—
Regardless of what you may think, Timber products play a huge role in making your daily life possible
@pistenbullyworld new Park Pro 400 snowcat shoving a fresh dump of Champagne powder the Okanagan Valley is famous for. The amount of snow these things can move is astounding!

A peek inside @northamericanconstructiongroup enormous shop at their Acheson HQ. I’ve walked a few shops in my travels, and always appreciate a well organized and clean facility
—
Who doesn’t get excited by 11 bays stuffed with yellow iron? All in for rebuilds at different stages of their usable lifespan
—
From individual component replacements and rebuilds, to full blown detailed frame up rebuilds. They do it all under North American’s shop roof. Tired iron rolls into the shop, and new iron rolls out ready to go to work building the infrastructure and mining the materials modern day civilization relies on

The faces of mining
—
Behind the scenes of modern day civilization you will find thousands of hard working people working tirelessly to extract the raw ingredients that make daily life possible for the rest of us
—
Long hours, night shifts, in all weather conditions, underground, remote work in off the grid locations, away from family, challenging, stressfull
—
But when you talk to these people, they are noticeably proud of what they do and why they do it. The nature of their career is incredibly rewarding
—
A career in mining isn’t for everyone, but anyone can make it in the mining industry with the right approach and attitude
—
As the industry seeks a future workforce and society’s approval of mining, we can’t mask the true story of mining. The caliber of people you will meet, genuine excitement of mining projects, and rewarding nature of the career ought to be shared

Celebrating Women in Construction week! Thank you to all the hard working women who build Canada’s highways, schools, bridges, underground infrastructure, homes, ports, grocery stores, railways, and more
—
Here is to another year strengthening and amplifying the success of women in construction. Without you, the industry wouldn’t be such a great place
—
“Many Paths, One Mission” is the National Association of Women in Construction theme for 2023. Together, we all work as a cohesive team to build the infrastructure of tomorrow
We are but a few days away from North America’s largest construction related gathering, @conexpoconagg 2023. Will you be attending the show? See you there! #conexpo2023
Here we go, day one of @conexpoconagg 2023! Hope to see you there!

That’s a wrap on North America’s largest Construction & Aggregate show, @conexpoconagg 2023. While equipment and technology is often the main event. The people, community, and learning opportunities are what truly make the show
—
While there are far more photos with people than I’ve ability to share, thank you to everyone I was able to meet, you are the reason this industry is such a great place!

D7 tidying up a logging spur road after cross pushing snow banks back to prep for spring break up (when snow melts and roads get soft/muddy) in the woods
-
This particular D7 is fitted with a @weldcobeales pioneering blade for year round road work deep in the mountains of British Columbia 
-
And yes, I know something is rattling on the cab/handrail

Cat’s new Trackwear Sensor (TWS) for digitally measuring undercarriage wear, arguably one of the neater finds at Conexpo!
—
As link height wears on undercarriage, a small sensor embedded in the track link detects wear on the track links (rails) using a short wire that wears with the undercarriage
—
The result? Real time wear measurements on links (rails) in your dozers undercarriage
—
On track type tractors of any size, undercarriage accounts for nearly 50% of overall ownership costs! Getting maximum life from your undercarriage and scheduling replacement is of interest for any sharp equipment manager or business owner
The hallmark of a great excavator operator in a cut? No clean up dozer chasing them around, see above for illustration. That cut is clean and tidy!

@timbermax_usa T20 winch assisting a TigerCat  L870 feller buncher down another steep slope here in British Columbia
—
Selective harvesting for mitigating fuel load in forests is becoming common practice to mitigate wildfire severity. The problem? A lot of fuel occurs on steep slopes, hence the need for winch assist logging
—
The winch in/out function is linked with the buncher operators travel pedals, so she’s a fully remote operated winch system. Neat!

GPS for big dozers! (Cat Terrain for Grading)
—
Operating as an indicate only (guidance) system, dozer hands can either work off a engineered file plan or manually inout to build a % slope to build a ramp, % side slope to reclaim an area, any simple design really!
—
Engineers post a file plan via satellite network, dozer operators can choose a design file depending on their work area, no survey required as cab mounted GPS tracks the dozers position
—
Second image shows a design file: Red is high (cut) green is on grade, and blue is (fill). The lines running across the screen shows an example slope profile. First video showing D10T with cab mounted GPS (Cat Terrain). Nifty!

Twin D6T’s in for undercarriage work at @heavymetalequipment Acheson facility 
—
These two will see new rails, pads, rollers, sprocket segments, attention to the equalizer bar & pivot shaft, and track frame NDT (non destructive testing) all before heading back out into the toughest application for undercarriage on earth, sand laden with oil
—
You never know what goodies you will find in HME’s shops!

Up in the cab of @mainlandconstructionmaterials new Cat 992 wheel loader. She’s 3 passes at a little over 20 metric ton per pass to fill one of three 775 haul trucks cycling to the gyratory crusher
—
It’s a full time gig producing vital construction materials for a growing world, and James the operator has been at it for 17 years, originally starting on an old Clark-Michigan loader
—
People regularly ask what I do for
Fun. My answer to them? A jump seat in a 992

Cat engineers: We are really excited to see how the new D7 performs in the dirt!

Canada: How about 8 feet of snow and -20C?

Cat engineers: 🥶
Sunrise at the dirt buffet @volvoce_na

Swipe to see the evolution of a haul truck rebuild at @northamericanconstructiongroup shop. It all comes apart, components get rebuilt, frame inspection, reassembled, and fully painted in a shorter time frame than one would think!

Office tour of @solanoresources Tigercat 632E Skidder
—
Four point harness in the seat, two joysticks to control nearly all functions, spinny seat, bubble gauge indicating tilt & roll of the machine, a lot of glass for visibility about all four corners of the cab
—
Skidders are responsible for skidding harvested wood to the lay down where a processor delimbs and sizes timber
A mother excavator and her youngest, the equipment kingdom is such a beautiful thing. @finningca

Cats R1700 next gen LHD (load-haul-dump) scooptram for underground mining, weighing in at 105,247lbs with a 10 cubic yard spade nose bucket affixed to the business end 
—
Neat facts about scoop trams:
- operator sits sideways
- they run slicks (bald tires)
- equipped with only spade nose flat lip buckets
- Hitch on the rear for recovering scoop, deactivates brakes when pulled
- are able to be cut in half for being lowered down mine shafts
- Wear bars welded to side of scoop for rubbing up against walls underground
—
While there isn’t a surface mining equivalent to the R1700, it nearly weighs as much as a 988K and can wield up to a 12 cubic yard bucket
Building the mines of tomorrow deep in the mountains of British Columbia @mackaybuilds

Pair of Sureway Construction’s 657E scrapers blading the cut first thing in the morning. The grader wasn’t available, so ejector forward and apron up the scrapers bladed the fill site flat to prepare for laying down lifts of earth

Mining matters in British Columbia!
—
Employing 35,000 people and contributing $18 billion to the economy in 2022, mining is an undeniable part of B.C.‘s economic pulse 
—
To supply a growing world with raw materials and fuel the economy, we need to continue developing mineral resources
—
Artemis Gold’s “Blackwater” open pit gold & silver project west of Prince George BC is the latest mine receiving federal approval to begin mine construction and eventual production
—
Over 8 million ounces of Au and 62 million ounces of Ag will come out of the current open pit design with a $150 million Cat equipment fleet supplied by Finning 
—
If you’ve wanted to jump into a career in Canadian Mining, now is a great time!

In true Canadian fashion, the annual spring @ritchiebros Edmonton auction is just around the corner, and it’s already sizing up to be one of the biggest at nearly 13,000 lots
—
Will it top 2015’s record of $215 million gross auction proceeds in just four days? Are you attending? If so, what are you bidding on?

Deep in the Canadian woods shoving back endless amounts of snow to keep roads open and British Columbia timber products moving to the mill. It’s a pretty good gig when you have the nicest office in the fleet!

Day in the life at Vinci’s Springbank dam project just West of Calgary, AB. With roughly 7 million cubes to move on a tight timeline, it’s a busy place keeping a spread of 773E rigids cycling and the dirt flowing
—
Neat fact about those 773E, some units are from Morocco and some from France. I hope they brought their passports and work Visa
Some push buttons on a keyboard, others push dirt. Both equally important jobs in a company, but I prefer the latter

More neat find(s)at Conexpo, this time at @amiattachmentsinc booth. Wrist buckets without exposed tilt cylinders, thumbs built into buckets with no exposed cylinders, and big buckets! (Including the XMOR product which is built in Canada 🇨🇦)
—
Swipe to see!

One of @sunshinevillage PistenBully 400 winch cats returning from a nightshift of laying down corduroy on steeps slopes. At nearly $500K price tag, these sure are the fanciest mobile offices at a ski resort

If it fits, it ships. Whissell’s 395 with an 84” digging bucket filling Tandem axle on highway trucks. It’s not too often you seeing 94 tonne of Cat yellow digging mainline and swinging in sections of pipe in your backyard

GIVEAWAY!
—
• Correctly guess the bucket manufacturer, bucket width, and rated cubic yard capacity (struck) —> Win a Yeti mug and T-shirt

• Funniest caption --> wins T-shirt and assortment of decals
—
First correct answer takes it, if no correct guesses, then first closest answer wins. 24hrs time limit from time of posting. Go!

When it comes to moving a few million cubes of earth in a jiffy, few machines can compete with the 657 scrapers ability to self load and eject (spread) 44 cubic yards of earth wherever you please on the jobsite
—
@surewayconstructiongroup has been building Alberta since the early 70’s, and they certainly are no stranger to moving a few million cubes on projects
—
If you’ve ever wanted to be trained on these big 657’s, now is your chance, they are indeed hiring!

Calgary’s Housing Boom!
—
Last year, Calgary realized a 62% increase in residential development, the highest observed in nearly a decade. Translating to ~15,000 new homes, a tall order for a city already butting up against the confines of the ring road
—
The result? Contractors have been busier than ever developing land for new homes as well as building underground and surface infrastructure to support it all. Never mind commercial/industrial development. 
—
“It’s going to be the busiest year we’ve ever had, we are actually turning down work”

“Our fleet is already busy and we can’t get new iron fast enough nor can we get enough people to do all the work”
—
Underpinned by a strong energy industry (Oil&Gas), immigration to capitalize on affordable housing (for now), and commerce/trade sector growth, it’s no wonder Alberta contractors are busier than ever!

Another load of BC Timber on its way to the mill and eventually into civilization as various timber products, thanks to the folks at @solanoresources
—
Above is a fine example why can risers are necessary when carefully stacking the final few pieces of timber atop a logging truck, visibility over the logs!

Fuelling time for Sureway’s 385C with their mobile fuel & lube truck
—
As job sites and equipment fleets get larger, it makes more sense to bring fuel to the equipment in the field, hence dedicated fuel and lube crews ensuring equipment is fuelled and greased daily
—
Carrying diesel, grease, coolant, transmission fluid, gear oil and more on an ADT chassis, this unit can realistically go anywhere on a jobsite for all your lubrication needs
Moving dirt for a new housing subdivision, the Alberta way, with @borgergroup and their fresh Hitachi EX1200-7

Building or bettering (rebuilding) our infrastructure!
—
@mackaybuilds Mounds project in Rogers Pass is a fine example, helping keep a vital thread of highway open year round allowing the economic heartbeat to continue
—
The 120m long, 20m high, and 118,000 cube thic avalanche berm is one of the many defences structures mitigating nearly 2000 avalanches per year in the Rogers Pass area
—
Snow comes down the mountain side, it catches it and prevents an avalanche from reaching the pavement
—
The impact blue collar people have on making civilization possible for the rest of us is astounding!
It was love at first sight when I found out she had a short stick and big bucket affixed to the business end

16 foot of blade making the rounds to keep haul roads in smooth order for a fleet of 657’s circling about
—
If you driven a rough road of any type, then you can certainly appreciate what a good blade hand can do in a few passes

Whissell’s 395 being fed bedding material by a wheel loader fitted with a gravel snout
—
Since the 395 has more reach than the wheel loader and the project corridor was rather confined on either side. The 395 placed bedding material to provide support and drainage for an feeder main in Southeast Calgary
The dirt equivalent to “my cup runneth over” @borgergroup

If it’s big dirt moving in Saskatchewan, it’s @kpcldirtmovers 
—
At their peak, they’ll move ~10 million cubes per season between Potash mine, highway, and railway construction
—
They are celebrating 70 years in the dirt business this year, and rightfully so. As a well established family run company, ownership knows the names of people in the field at all levels, and there’s a certain people oriented culture about their sites
—
If you like big equipment, big dirt projects, great people, food & accommodations provided (camp), they are hiring for a busy season!
—
And heck, why not work in the “land of the living skies”

A collective 1,900 horsepower of 657 scraper in push-pull formation scooping up 88 cubes of earth in under 45 seconds. Nothing says Alberta Construction like big equipment on big cubic yardage residential development projects

Hitachi’s newest addition to their 120 tonne class offering, and @borgergroup newest addition to their fleet, an EX1200-7
—
Beginning in 1919 with a Sanitary line install at the Winnipeg International Airport with only men and shovels, Borger Group’s near century long history is coloured by innovation, family values, and hard work
—
Today, they are a multi division company building Alberta as we all know it
—
With the EX1200 now the largest in the fleet (previously a 90 tonne machine) they are jumping head first into large earthworks projects and mining contracting
—
Nothing says ‘we mean business moving dirt’ like ~120tonne of Hitachi orange!

@kpcldirtmovers 127 tonne Cat 5110B putting in a honest days work loading out 50 tonne 772 rigid frames
—
The 5000 series hoes were simple, worked hard, all power and no Def. A simpler time when turbos screamed through unobstructed exhaust pipes
—
KPCL operates two of these 5110’s moving dirt full time in Saskatchewan!

@acresenterprisesltd 299D3 skidsteer equipped with a 2.4m Cat grader blade and Trimble earthworks. The first of its kind in Western Canada!
—
Fitted with a prism or GPS receiver, in cab touch screen, modem with SIM card for receiving file plans from the office in the field, wings, and wheels up front add length to the unit for grading stability. In the right material, she’s a finish grade machine!
—
While some would argue “why don’t you use a real grader”, the grader blade attachment can do things a full size grader can’t and makes the skidsteer more versatile on the jobsite

The Cat folks remotely operating an Excavator in Arizona and Skidsteer in North Carolina. They put on a great demo of their Cat Command technology at Conexpo 2023, did you get a chance to run the one of the pieces (excavator, dozer, skidsteer, or wheel loader) remotely from Las Vegas?

A pair of @heavymetalequipment D6’s in for undercarriage repair, after a few thousand hours in the toughest application for undercarriage (oil laden sand)
—
These two will get just about new everything (rollers, track frame welding, pivot shaft work, rails, etc) underneath before they are back to work. One of the few times you will see dozers up on blocks like this!

@mackaybuilds newest addition to their mining fleet with a serial # ending in 001 (first in the world!), a Hitachi EX2000-7 in backhoe configuration
—
As MacKay’s mining division has grown to take on larger projects, so has their fleet with the addition of 200tonnes of Hitachi orange
—
It’s a real treat visiting their mining projects, every time I’m filled by genuine excitement that I just can’t shake. The big equipment, the people, big earthmoving, there’s just something special about it all

@borgergroup single engine 631 scrapers in action scooping up 34 cubes of earth. While not that common, single engine scrapers are a lower cost to operate with the caveat of a D10 babysitting them in the cut push loading

Up in the cab of @mackaybuilds Hitachi EX2000-7 excavator. When it comes to moving a lot of overburden in a jiffy, she’s the heavy weight, sporting a 16 cubic yard bucket loading out Cat 777 rigid frames
Big girl on the move @kpcldirtmovers

Training your people! One of @mackaybuilds new 777 haul truck operators getting operator training
—
Whenever a new hire joins their team, they get equipment specific training that includes an experienced operator riding along in the cab to provide mentorship
—
While training has always been a facet of the industry, it has risen to become more important today to not only replace those retiring, but add to the workforce as mining itself prepares for a busy decade ahead
Walk around of @acresenterprisesltd 299D3 with Trimble earthworks and a Cat GB124 (2.4m wide) grader blade, she is one of the first to be spec’d like this in Western Canada!
Happy Canada Day! 🇨🇦 Here’s to celebrating not only our nations birthday, but the hard working people who build Canada! (Including demolition!)
@borgergroup EX1200 getting after it starting a cut. Peek how clean that floor is! No clean up dozer chasing this fella around

A spread of high sprocket side boom pipelayers at @ritchiebros Edmonton auction last year. Once used to lay the very pipe that moves our nations energy resources to global markets, they now seek a new home
—
Nothing says fun like casually picking up a Deere 470G with one of these

Inside the cab of BelPacific’s 336E long reach, it’s a long way down to the dirt!
—
While the operator can see over the edge in this instance, there’s a cab mounted camera to assist when visibility to the bucket is not available. And yes, those are wood blocks under the travel pedals to prevent travelling the machine

Cat’s best kept secret in their dozer lineup, the D9!
—
The nimble attitude of a D8 with the muscle of a D10. She can clean up your pit floor, bulk material, rip frost and/or rock, or push scrapers-no complaints!
—
40,000lbs lighter than her larger sibling, the 9 is a delightful blend of horsepower and weight up to most all dirt tasks
—
Besides that, they are a sharp looking tractor-the only one in the lineup still sporting an exhaust flapper may I add!
@kpcldirtmovers

Nightshift up in the cab of @mackaybuilds 200 tonne Hitachi loading out overburden. Contrary to the 9-5 mon-fri work week in other industries, mining is 24hrs a day 365 days a year to provide the necessary raw ingredients for civilization

Deepest excavation in Vancouver history!
—
BelPacific Excavating & Shoring 133ft deep dig at 1515 Alberni Street preparing for 42 stories of high rise to follow (swipe to see)
—
Deep digs like this are for the sole purpose of underground parking requirements
—
Excavation advances in lifts, shoring of the walls with steel anchors, rebar/mesh, and shotcrete chasing the excavation down
—
Exporting dirt progresses from excavators, to long reach, to telestick excavator finishing the deepest portion of dirt export
—
After that, all equipment is craned out from 133ft to street level and it’s onto the next one!
What a beautiful sight, Canadian flag flying proud atop a D8T with Trimble Technology @vinciconstruction

@kpcldirtmovers assembling their 374F
—
Once it is off the truck it’s but a few hours to assemble between two mechanics. Counterweight is hoisted up and bolted on, stick and bucket pinned on, then all associated hydraulic plumbing connected
—
Pretty soon she’ll be loading 745 wiggles with a @weldcobeales spade, her happy place

When it comes to mining, big dozers like the D11 are often tool of choice for ripping and pushing
—
It’s all about big horsepower and weight (tractive effort) pulling a few feet of ripper shank through solid earth. At 248,500lbs and 850 net horsepower, she’s more than capable!

@propeller_aero DirtMate technology in the wild on @borgergroup equipment, the first deployment of its kind in Canada!
—
From a cab mounted, solar powered, survey grade sensor. Elevation data below the tracks or tires is collected, processed, and integrated with regular drone surveys
—
The end result? Real time volumes of dirt moved, cut/fill heatmaps, load counts, and machine utilization captured by the built in IMU
—
It’s a neat take on capturing real time site data to ultimately help drive better decision making on projects and accurately track metrics
Cat’s 395 vs. Deere’s 870 up against Volvo’s 950! Which ~90 tonne machine are you choosing for your dirt moving operations and why?
Producing the crucial aggregate materials to build the modern day infrastructure we all rely upon, one 988 bucketful at a time. @mainlandconstructionmaterials

Frost buster (ripper attachment) for an EX1200 built for tough Canadian winters from @weldcobeales Edmonton Facility
—
WBM started embedding blue tooth chips dubbed “smart tags” on their attachments so customers could query parts books, maintenance guides, GET details, and other serial tag data from their phone when nearby

The largest high reach in Canada!
—
@priestlydemolition Kobelco SK1600D, 1 of 13 high reaches in their 250+ piece fleet of equipment
—
Originally beginning its life in Japan, then with a group in California, PDI purchased and mobilized the SK1600 to Canada for demolishing tall structures-like this 10 story in Calgary, Alberta
—
Weighing 398,000lbs she reaches 167ft to the pin, over 170ft with a 6,000lb Okada  processor fitted. Unlike most high reaches with 3 boom sections, this machine’s boom is configurable with 4 sections: boom, mid stick, stick, and stinger (stinger is a stick from a Cat 330 long reach!)
—
Currently Matt Baker and Rob Morrison, two of PDI’s many skilled high reach operators, are piloting this high reach munching on concrete and rebar 170ft+ in the air
Back out to visit the folks at @heavymetalequip this week, stay tuned for a peek behind the scenes one of the largest heavy equipment rental outfits in North America!

Vinci Construction’s custom built temporary bridge over Hwy 22. The bridge allows 773 rigid frames and public traffic to safely flow uninterrupted
—
Excavating a 4.3km long diversion channel and building a 3.8km long 29m high earth dam requires Vinci to move millions of cubes across the project for fill purposes. Their solution to crossing a highway? Build a bridge!

BelPacific’s 352 casting up to a 349 bailing to a 336 long reach loading out dirt to trucks + pups at street level
—
When there is dirt to export from a 133ft deep dig, it’s all hands on deck!
—
While BelPacific typically sends excavated material to a marine disposal facility via belly dump barge, dirt from this particular site was sent to a land based disposal facility
Building Alberta, one bucket at a time @borgergroup

Closer look at BelPacific’s 336E spec’d with a 60ft long reach
—
Her main task is to scoop ~3yards of dirt from deep in the excavation and load trucks+pups at street level. It’s a delicate task in an urban downtown setting
—
While the operator can typically see over the edge to the bucket, a stick mounted camera with in cab screen is installed for good measure when visibility to the bucket isn’t ideal
—
And yes, that is a wood block under the travel pedals

Moving earth to build the final 9km section of Calgary’s 101km long ring road, apart from SR1 offstream reservoir this is one of the more notable infrastructure projects in Alberta this decade
—
Current project progress is much further along, these photos are a few years old.

Big girl on the move! @priestlydemolition 
—
At ~200 tonne the Kobelco SK1600 may not be fast on her feet moving into position, but she can easily nibble on concrete and rebar 170ft+ high!

18 years old at the helm of 90tonne of Cat yellow
—
Intentionally developing people, no matter age or prior career, is @kpcldirtmovers approach to building the workforce of tomorrow
—
People thrive on opportunity and purpose
—
Opportunity? If you can learn a rock truck, you can learn a 120 tonnne excavator, or even work up to running projects. Purpose? You are part of building the infrastructure we all rely on and get to look back on major infrastructure or mining projects well into the future

Women in Mining!
-
Janel, one of the many women at @mackaybuilds, started with MacKay as a haul truck operator and recently moved into the role of D10 dozer operator
—
If running big equipment in the mountains of British Columbia peeks your interest, the folks at MacKay have plenty opportunity in their mining division!

Up in the cab of @mainlandconstructionmaterials new 992 NG production wheel loader. With 360 visibility, touch screen(s), joystick steering, heat/cooled seat, and built in lunch cooler, it’s one of the nicest cabs I’ve ever been in

@irt_1980 hauling 205,000lbs of @heavymetalequipmentandrentals Cat 793F on 76 wheels
—
A Kenworth T800 leads the charge up front with a C500 pushing in the rear, complete with two jeeps and training wheels or stubs as some would call them
—
This 793F originally came from Chile, went through Heavy Metal’s Spruce Grove facility, and now headed to work for a customer in Northern Alberta
On this episode of ‘spot the mechanic’ ft. 240,000lbs of Cat dozer @borgergroup

Here’s to those working long weekends, nightshifts, in rain or snow, long days, away from home to build Canada as we know it. Happy Labour Day, and thank you, your contribution to society does not go unrecognized!

Street level with BelPacific’s 336E long reach as it lifts another ~3 cubes of earth from 60ft deep
—
Downtown Vancouver is a busy place and they were tasked with street loading truck & pup with an adjacent active lane. Always a pleasure watching the folks at BelPacific build Vancouver!

Building a core trench with @kpcldirtmovers
—
In order to retain liquids in tailings storage facilities (tailings ponds), core or key trenches are built to prevent seepage through porous dirt
—
A trench is excavated to bedrock or an impermeable layer, then backfilled with good clay soil, forming a vertical barrier confining materials/liquids within the tailings pond. See illustration above!
—
Engineering features like this are important components of TSF’s at mine sites around the world!

Loading the shot for a blast with Western Grater, part of @norlandlimited 
—
Using bulk explosive commonly known as ANFO (ammonium nitrate and diesel fuel), certified blasters send the charge down followed by water resistant ANFO (blue) to mitigate effects of any groundwater, followed by regular ANFO (orange)
—
A tamping stick is used to settle the ANFO in the hole and gauge amount of explosive used
—
The final step after all holes are loaded tieing in the blast by connecting holes in sequential order, and then blast!
Building Saskatchewan, one bucket full at a time @kpcldirtmovers

Westmill Roadworks cold planer eating up temporary pavement on the Coquihalla highway
—
A large rotating drum with carbide teeth mulches asphalt into little bits and sends it via conveyor into a tandem axle. Mulched asphalt is then recycled in the asphalt production process
—
Sadly, the infrastructure society commutes on is rarely appreciated until it’s broken.

What’s bedding material used for anyway?
—
The infrastructure buried beneath us (water, sewer, storm water pipes) ability to last many decades and resist overlying earth loads is influenced by the structural support of bedding material
—
Depending on the type of pipe, clean granular bedding material is placed underneath, around, and on top of pipe to provide vertical and horizontal support, in addition to allowing for drainage of water from around the pipe
—
Thanks to blue collar folk installing underground utilities, your home has clean water on demand at the turn of a tap

Vinci Construction’s Volvo 950F loading Cat 773E with dirt from a 4.3km long diversion channel at the SR1 project West of Calgary along the Elbow River
—
But one of the many 773 loads to haul ~5 million cubes of earth for an off-stream reservoir and dam, a project critical to Alberta’s flood mitigation infrastructure

@borgergroup D10T on retreat after push loading a 631 scraper. Those who think Cat work is an easy life of putting the blade down and foot off decel pedal have never managed/pushed a spread of 631’s in the cut!
@mackaybuilds 2019 Kenworth T800 bringing 112,916lbs of Deere 470G down the hill on their new custom green @aspentrailers! It’s always a good day when the sun is shining and Jake brakes are singing

@priestlydemolition Komatsu PC490 fitted with a 12,000lb @epirocgroup CC5000 processor feasting on the lower floors of a 10 story project
—
Once all salvageable and hazardous materials are removed, a concrete and rebar skeleton is all that remains
—
Processor attachments both crush concrete and shear structural rebar by brute force, reducing a building to rubble in short order!
—
Swipe to see @demolitionman100 for scale!

Dakota Reclamators (part of @priestlydemolition), flood mitigation project in the Bow River circa 2022 was one of the neater applications of @trimblecec GPS technology I can recall
—
As the industry has grown to accept it, technology is an undeniably key component to any modern day dirt project
—
Working blind underwater required their dozer hand, Abe, to go from feel of the tractor/blade, in addition to what the GPS indicated as design. Compared to normal dirt work, rebuilding a river channel underwater presents a different scope of challenges
—
This is still one of the more memorable projects where technology has helped a contractor succeed!

Matt, production excavator operator for @mackaybuilds mining division, shares how he got started at MacKay. Whether you have experience or not, MacKay is a great place to start a career in mining in the most scenic part of Canada, the mountains of British Columbia! #canadianmining

What do us Canadians do in the winter when dirt is frozen, push snow of course!
—
WBM pioneering blade, cab sweeps, lighting package, triple shank ripper, undercarriage guarding. Little over $1 million of yellow tractor right there!

One from the archives today, a neat piece of kit I stumbled across for precisely joining PVC pipe together. Much preferred method over what some do with an excavator bucket pushing on the end of the pipe! 
—
Please note, angle of video makes the trench look deeper than it is, edges are sloped appropriately for the material.

Swipe to see before and after of a 24 grader rebuild at @heavymetalequipmentandrentals Spruce Grove facility
—
Their technicians do top tier work on par with a certified rebuild from dealer/OEM. This unit is off to smooth roads in Eastern Canada!

Women in Construction
—
Jennifer, one of @kpcldirtmovers haul truck operators, shares her experience starting a career in the dirt moving industry
—
The folks at KPCL are firm believers in training people, no matter age of prior career. If you’ve got the right attitude and work ethic, you get a chance to learn and grow in the company. An admirable approach!

@mackaybuilds 385C shipping 100tonne of metallurgical coal from the pit
—
After overburden is removed down to the ‘parting layer’ (where coal seams meet hard rock) the metallurgical coal seam, however thick, is loaded out with excavators into rigid frame haul trucks
—
Metallurgical coal is an essential ingredient for steel making, one of the building blocks for society as we know it!

In honour of National track loader week, I present to you Whissell’s (now E360S) 963K track loader, customized for landfill applications
—
While dirt and rock can be hard on iron, garbage is exceptionally so because of the non homogenous mixture of waste material (pianos, steel, batteries, residential waste, wood, food waste, and more!)
—
Whissell’s 963K is modified to push, crawl over, and compact waste. I annotated the first image to show some of the modifications 
—
People still look at me weird for calling these traxcavators 🤷🏼‍♂️ #trackloaderweek

Happy Thanksgiving from your favourite Canadian dirt enthusiast, may your plates be as full of food as these wiggles are of dirt
—
Thank you to those in the construction and mining world working through the holiday to keep society functioning

Construction of @inside_bhp underground Jansen Potash mine in Saskatchewan. BHP is investing $7.5billion CAD into JS1 (Jansen Stage 1)
—
Canada is the #1 producer of Potash in world! Accounting for 31% of the 71.9 million tonne per annum production, and I’m proud of it
—
Canada has some of the finest mineral resources on the planet, I would argue the most socially and environmentally responsible mining practices
—
Potassium Carbonate (K2CO3) is primary use is in the form of fertilizer to produce the very food you eat
—
Swipe to see! Headframe and underground photo courtesy of BHP. Other photos taken from a secret plane.

@brodagroup 390F making its morning commute to work
—
The 390 is but one of many pieces completing earthworks on a major interchange and road widening project in Cochrane, Alberta
—
A keen eye will spot narrow pads and four tooth bucket for, you guessed it, digging in tough material

@cmt_ventures hauling @heavymetalequipmentandrentals rebuilt 789C from Spruce Grove to Ft McKay
—
The “Cruel Mistress” Peterbuilt up front with a Western star pushing 316,517lbs of Cat yellow spanning 22ft wide and 177ft long. The 789C went through a full frame up rebuild, yet again fantastic work by Heavy Metal’s skilled heavy equipment technicians
—
I field a guess there is more rubber on the road than the average person will buy in tires in their lifetime!  Video credit @cmt_ventures
@brodagroup 390F getting speedy loading out 773/775 rigid frames while people make their morning commute to work in the background on a major highway interchange project in Cochrane, Alberta
You know it’s mining when the cleanup dozer is a D11T @mackaybuilds

Loading the shot for a quarry blast (watch till end for blast) with Western Grater, part of @norlandlimited 
—
Quarried rock product is one of the building blocks of the modern day world we live in, and this is where it begins its journey before crushing and screening/sizing!

Construction of the 4.3km long diversion channel at Vinci’s SR1 off-stream reservoir project
—
After the top layer of loose earth is bulked out by conventional method of excavators and trucks, big dozers move in to rip and push Alberta silt/sandstone. It’s a tough job, not a problem for Cat dozers.

@timbermax_usa T20 winch assisting @solanoresources TigerCat feller buncher down a steep slope
—
Naturally, terrain in British Columbia is steep, so contractors like Solano use winch systems to navigate and selectively log areas
—
This particular Timbermax winch can exert 20 ton of pull force on all 1,380ft of 1” cable which connects to the frame (last photo)
Back out to visit the folks at BelPacific Excavating & Shoring LP tomorrow on Vancouver’s deepest excavation to date, stay tuned!

657 scraper cruising by on an early Alberta morning @surewayconstructiongroup
—
There’s no faster way to move dirt than a motor scraper that self loads in the cut and self unloads in the fill
Throwback to the good ol days when @schrimpy_wimpy was running rock truck and Bill on the 390 moving a few thousand cubes in the mountains of BC. What a time to be alive! @mackaybuilds
Loading out rigid frames at sunrise @brodagroup

@kpcldirtmovers unique D8T spec’d with 38” pads for flotation and 16’ long straight blade
—
The D8T spreads ‘random fill’ on a tailings pond perimeter dyke raise, it’s the ideal machine for when you need a bit more muscle than a D6 but don’t want to sacrifice flotation offered by a lighter tractor
—
A constant stream of 745’s bring in fill from the cut not too far away in the distance

Cat’s 6015B loading 7460 E-Ject wagons, a custom product line of pull behind ejector style wagons that Cat purchased and briefly carried
—
Their purpose was to increase the capacity of the regular 740 rock truck by 40% and decrease ground pressure by 12%, without going to a larger haul unit obviously
—
They are decent units, work well spreading on the fly at fill sites, but sadly only on flat hauls do they really shine as the standard 740 ain’t made for pulling that much weight up hill (Hello transmission issues!)

@brodagroup 390 and fleet of 773 completing the bulk earthworks component of a major interchange upgrade between Highway 1A and 22 in Cochrane, Alberta
—
While Broda Group is a well known contractor in central Canada (primarily Saskatchewan), they recently expanded into Alberta with work on multiple fronts in the Province and a large fleet of iron to accompany it
—
The Cat 390 pairs nicely with almost any truck. Tandem on highways, wiggles, or in this case 733/75 rigid frames

We recently visited a new Cat D9, delivered by @finningca, pushing in stockpile application
—
The D9 is arguably Cat’s best kept secret in their dozer lineup, power of a D10 yet nimble like a D8, they are becoming a more popular tractor across the industry
—
Stockpile dozer means one thing, massive blade! D11 size @weldcobeales blade on a D9 to be specific

Close up of @irt_1980 hauling @heavymetalequipmentandrentals 793F from Edmonton --> Ft McKay
—
205,000lbs spread out over 76 wheels, complete with two jeeps and stubs/training wheels with Kenworth T800 pulling and C500 shoving. Where else in the world can you watch a 793F navigate public roads? Alberta of course!
--
Believe it or not, this isn’t even Heavy Metal’s largest truck in their fleet!
Building the Canadian infrastructure we all rely, one D8 blade full at a time. @vinciconstruction

@kpcldirtmovers collaborating with @pcl_construction on Tunnel #5 outflow repair at the Gardiner Dam
—
To replace erosion protection at the toe of the Tunnel outflow, KPCL built a cofferdam for excavation to proceed. Once wet excavation was complete, geotextile cloth is placed, with 6” minus bedding overtop and Class C rip rap to complete to total 2.2m thick lift of material protecting the toe of the outflow structure
—
Gardiner Dam is a significant piece of infrastructure in Saskatchewan, the largest embankment dam in Canada since construction in the late 1950’s, generating 186 MW (megawatts) of power!
--
It's one of the neater projects I've visited, a fine example of the significant role modern day infrastructure has in making civilization possible!

@brodagroup D9R push loading their 657E scrapers in the cut
—
While the 657 can self load, or buddy up to push-pull load one another, sometimes a dozer is called for. Typically D9 or greater, the dozer push loads the scraper in the cut helping scoop up 44 cubes of earth in under a minute
—
The motor scraper is a natural born dirt mover!

Tolko's new D9, relieving an older D8R of it's duties in stockpile application
--
While the D9 falls into Cat's mining class dozer lineup (D9-D11), this particular machine isn't in mining. Instead, it pushes "hog fuel" (mixture of bark and other tree bits) in stockpile application, spec'd with a 60 cubic yard D11 size @weldcobeales blade
--
I always appreciate seeing unique applications for big dozers
--
One neat fact about this machine, given the blade is light and D9 already well balanced, the additional counterweight wasn’t needed so a smaller counterweight/storage solution was fitted in place!

BelPacific Excavating & Shoring LP telestick reaching 100ft+ scooping up 1.7 cubes of earth to load out tandem axles on the street
—
At 6-7 scoops per truck, averaging 215 cubes of earth per day, the telestick certainly isn’t fast like a regular excavator, but what else can reach 35m deep into a hole in the heart of downtown Vancouver?

@mackaybuilds building the $13.5 million debris flow mitigation structure on Coldspring Creek in Fairmont Hotsprings
—
After a devastating mudslide rushed down coldstring creek in July of 2012, plowing through homes, highways, and a golf course, the Regional District of East Kootenay set forth to mitigate the natural hazard by building barrier and outlet structure to capture debris
—
The completed structure (dam) will be 8m high, 28m wide, and 250m across requiring 20,000 cubes of roller compacted concrete poured and compacted over 40 days. Upstream of the dam, a creek diversion with Tyrolean Weir separates water from debris, escorting debris to a collection point while waters flows freely
—
While some think MacKay is purely a dirt contractor, they do technical civil builds like this too, including a unique “roller compacted concrete” technique for building the concrete debris flow structure (dam)
Dirt shipping department in full swing @kpcldirtmovers

Underground Mining! Ride along in a Sandvik 50 tonne (TH663i) rock truck making it way to surface loaded with waste rock
—
No different than a wiggle wagon on surface, just underground in a dark environment with but a few feet between the truck and solid rock
—
Since developing underground infrastructure is incredibly expensive per meter, the drifts (tunnels) are only made as wide as necessary, meaning the haul truck just fits!

A unique reclamation practice we developed and use here in Canadian mining called “Rough Mounding” during placement of coversoil
--
After a mine is closed and slopes are recontoured, coversoil is harvested from stockpiles and spread overtop in a 30cm layer. Once adequate coverage is achieved, a bulldozer reverses up slope creating small mounds of coversoil as it retreats
--
The end result is a pattern of small mounds that encourages native vegetation to take by retaining seeds, nutrients, and water in the microrelief created by mounds which in turn also prevents erosion of soils on slopes
--
Canada has some of the most environmentally and socially responsible mining in the world, and I’m proud of it!

Rebuilt D11T being hauled nearly fully dressed (minus ROPS, blade, push arms, shank) back to work in the oilsands
—
With a population well into the hundreds, the D11 is tractor of choice for many oilsands mine operators and contractors
—
A keen eye will spot blankets protecting front and rear windows, plus covers over the exhaust stacks during transport

Progress on Vancouver’s deepest excavation to date! The 130ft+ deep 1515 Alberni Street dig
—
BelPacific Excavating & Shoring LP tele stick excavator with 35m reach has relieved their 60ft long reach of its duties, the telestick excavates earth from over 100ft deep to load trucks at street level. By completion of BelPacific’s scope, 56,000 cubes will have been excavated!
—
As excavations get deeper to accommodate taller high rises, parking requirements, and reduced building footprint, contractors like BelPacific have to bring unique equipment solutions to excavate earth from deep holes in the heart of downtown Vancouver. It’s always a treat to watch the professionals at BelPacific help build the Vancouver skyline!
—
The end product will be a 41 floor, 439ft tall building with 8 levels of parkade below (swipe to see rendering)

Ground breaking at @heavymetalequipmentandrentals new 100,000 sq ft, 12 bay service centre in Fort McKay Industrial Park, Alberta
—
As their fleet has expanded, so has the need for indoor shop space to service one of the largest rental fleets in North America
—
The new shop will be next door to their existing facility, adding much needed space to better serve clients and service their fleet (everything from oil changes to full rebuilds and more), alongside additional employment opportunities
—
Naturally, the bays will be large enough to accompany haul trucks like a 777, up to and including a 797F + box to pull in and be serviced, amongst other large pieces in the fleet!

Tolko’s new Cat D9, delivered by @finningca, relieving a D8R of its duties stockpiling hog fuel (mixture of tree bark and other tree bits), both tractors are spec’d with @weldcobeales blades, but the D9 yields a larger 60 cube D11 size blade
—
Amazing the think since 1955 the D9 tractor family has grown to a population of over 40,000! Through many iterations/models of course
—
And yes I used the phrase “more oopmh” to describe the reasoning for a larger dozer in this application

Building a perimeter dyke with @kpcldirtmovers!
—
Forming the encompassing walls of a new fine tailings storage facility (cell), a perimeter dyke consists of a clay core with random fill* making up the outer slopes. The clay core + key trench (see illustration) is an impermeable layer preventing seepage of liquids/fines through the dyke
—
775’s haul good clay fill off the 5110B for the dyke core, while 745’s haul random fill off the 390 to form up the slopes of the dyke surrounding the core. Dozers, a grader, and a sheep foot computer build up the dyke in lifts
—
The final earth structure will be 10m tall and 8m wide at the top, with a 3:1 slope down to a 60m wide base + chimney drain on one portion. Thanks to the work of KPCL, Potash mines like this can continue to produce potash, used primarily in fertilizer, to ultimately feed the world!
—
*Random fill being another term for common excavation or similar, it’s good dirt.

@komatsumining newest iteration of their largest production dozer, the D475a-8, with @raptormining RaptorPlate fitted on the 60 cubic yard super-dozer blade
—
The chromium carbide overlay best protects from wear caused by material sliding over a surface, such as dirt/rock sliding across a dozer blade
—
Naturally, since chrome is an ingredient, the blade polishes to a beautiful shine revealing Raptor’s signature mark, a zigzag weld pattern on the RaptorPlate wear product
—
In incredibly abrasive applications like hard rock mining, GET and wear products serve as sacrificial metal protecting underlying structural metal from wear causing unscheduled downtime
@mackaybuilds new 330 side by side with their trusty 336E ditching for a culvert install at the Coldspring Creek debris flow mitigation project

Reclamation in Canadian Mining!
--
I’m a big advocate for Canadian Mining, we have some of the finest natural resources in the world, alongside the most environmentally and socially responsible mining practices to extract them
--
Norcon Construction’s work helping reclaim a metallurgical coal mine is a fine example of the end goal Canadian mining companies strive towards, and frankly take great pride in  
--
Once complete, the reclaimed land is returned to a productive state and soon home to animals like bighorn sheep, elk, mule deer, grizzly bear, and wolf, to name a few

One of the larger haul trucks in @catmining lineup and newest addition to @heavymetalequipmentandrentals fleet, a 797F, pulling in to their Fort McKay facility
—
I’ve already lost count of how many new haul trucks Heavy Metal Equipment has added to the fleet in the last year
—
When it comes to big equipment rentals in the mining industry, it’s Heavy Metal Equipment!

One of the stages of reclaiming recontoured slopes, coversoil placement and “rough mounding” of coversoil with bulldozers
—
Norcon Construction’s Komatsu D71 spreads a 30cm thick layer of coversoil overtop recontoured overburden piles, followed by a technique called “rough mounding” where the dozer creates small mounds staggered on the slope. This prevents erosions and encourages vegetation to re-establish 
—
A finished product is visible in the background showing the mounds, woody debris, and vegetation beginning to take

Slot dozing!
—
A fine example of what you can accomplish with a little tractor in the right dozing setup
—
Dozers are most effective at pushing material in a slot where adjacent windrows help heap material in front of the blade
—
The R series Cat’s are still the finest on the market in my opinion

235,000lbs (when loaded) of Cat 775D crossing Alberta’s Highway 22
—
@brodagroup rigid frames hauling earth from the cut to fill site, the only route, cross a highway!
—
With Traffic control in place, temporary thick metal sheets were laid down to facilitate the big trucks carrying earth over the highway

The Calgary Ring Road is Complete!
—
Yesterday marked the opening day for the final 9km stretch of Calgary’s 101km long ring road, after nearly 25 years of construction, $4 billion dollars, 197 bridges, 48 interchanges, a billion gallons of diesel, and god knows how many cubes of Alberta dirt moved
—
With planning dating back to the 1950’s, land acquisition and detailed plans in the 1970’s, construction on the first section began in 1999 and the final section, west Calgary ring road (WCRR), beginning construction in 2019 now wrapping up in late 2023
—
One thing I’ve always admired about Alberta is their infrastructure, its built dam well. I was fortunate enough to tour the Southern portion of WCRR with Richardson Brother’s. 6015B feeding ejector wagons, D10’s shoving pull behind scrapers, and more, they are a serious earthmoving outfit that not many know about
—
Next time you enjoy modern day infrastructure like the ring road, thank your local dirt contractor
Big blades and big horsepower, D9 NG (next gen) stockpiling hog fuel (mixture of bark and other tree bits)

Another year older, another year full of great experiences with great people. Swipe to see where it all started. Same idea, just larger equipment in a bigger dirt theatre.
—
Thanks to all friends, clients, and people I met that made it a great year, you are the reason this industry is a great place!

Excavator —> Long reach —> Telestick Excavator —> Crane excavators out. Swipe to see BelPacific’s progress at 1515 Alberni street project. Today is the final step in the deep excavation process, craning a 349 and 352 from the hole!
Santa tracking my Christmas present over to hide underneath the tree. I wrote him asking for something that would load 40 tonners in two scoops, looks like he’s gonna deliver!

The largest aggregate deposit in Canada! The 100+ million tonne ‘Sandhill’ mine in Kitimat BC is the largest naturally occurring mound of well grading sand and gravel in Canada (maybe North America). Initially deposited by a glacier in a large mound.
—
Funfact about the two D11T on site, they are Twins (sequential serial number) coming from a stockpile application (hence the counterweight - no ripper), Sandhill sold one to @goldrushparker, and other is still up for sale! (This one)
—
Dozers shove endless amounts of material down off Sandhill to a fleet of wheel loaders which either load trucks, load a crushing plant, or load a wash plant which produces various products
If there’s one Canadian contractor that can move a mountain of dirt in a jiffy, it’s @kpcldirtmovers

The largest tele-stick excavator in North America!
—
BelPacific Excavating & Shoring LP custom built tele-stick excavator with 35m of vertical reach! Built on a Cat 349E carrier by @vanedequipment fitted with Italian made @cosbenequipmentconstruction tele-stick and 1.7 cubic yard clam shell bucket
—
The 349 received additional counterweight to accommodate the tele stick, increased hydraulic reservoir capacity, and stick mounted camera with in cab screen
—
As excavations get deeper to accommodate taller high rises, parking requirements, and reduced building footprint, contractors like BelPacific have to bring unique equipment solutions to excavate earth from over 130ft deep on Vancouver’s deepest dig to date, 1515 Alberni Street

@heavymetalequipmentandrentals latest addition to their hydraulic mining shovel fleet in Canada, a @komatsumining PC7000-11 supplied and serviced by @smsequipment 
—
With a fleet of 28 hydraulic shovels, the largest in the world for an independent company, Heavy Metal’s equipment fleet has expanded to meet the needs of mining customers thanks to their team of people, and partnerships with dealerships like SMS
—
Beginning its journey in Germany, the PC7000 arrived by boat, followed by on highway transport via multiple tractor trailer loads to Alberta for assembly. Spec’d in front shovel configuration with a 50 cubic yard spade, she’ll load a 250 ton haul truck in a mere 4 passes
—
Nothing brings a smile to my face like big mining equipment!
—
Photo credits: SMS Equipment

The largest earthen dam in Canada!
—
Built between 1958-1967 at a cost of $120 million CAD, the 65 million cubic meter 64m high by 5,000m long Gardiner Dam, in connection with the Qu’Appelle River Dam created Lake Diefenbaker (Saskatchewan’s “Great” Lake!). It was a different time in the industry, when the dress code was business casual, open cabs were in style, emissions weren’t regulated, and equipment was made to last
—
Gardiner Dam is named after Saskatchewan’s Premier of the time, James Gardiner.  If you flick through the archival photos (Courtesy of Saskatoon Public Library) you can get a sense of project magnitude and equipment used during construction
—
Currently the dam supplies irrigation water to much of Saskatchewan and constant flow of water to the Coteau Creek Hydroelectric Station producing 186MW (megawatts) of electricity
—
Fast forward to 2023, @kpcldirtmovers and @pcl_construction partnered on reconstruction of rip rap at the toe of Tunnel #5, regular maintenance to keep the structure functional. It’s neat to see how critical infrastructure like this has stood the test of time, and a testament to the significance of construction in making civilization possible

MacKay Builds, Hauls, Mines, and more! They are an incredibly diverse company where you can get into mining, technical civil work, bulk earthworks projects, aggregates/quarrying, heavy haul, and more across all of their divisions in Canada and even Internationally! @mackaybuilds

Swipe to see a few (certainly not all) oilsand specific modifications to @heavymetalequipmentandrentals 797F
—
While many modifications are function driven, majority of them are driven by safety, making these yellow Goliaths safer on a mine site
—
Naturally, since the oilsands is home of the 797, @finningca and Heavy Metal Equipment have the shop facilities and people for repairing, rebuilding, and modifying these massive trucks with ease
—
I find it super neat to see equipment specific modifications across different Canadian mine sites
Big blade in the neighbourhood on road smoothing duty @mackaybuilds

Craning out two excavators from a 100+ ft deep hole!
—
@kansencrane craning out BelPacific’s 349 and 352 from Vancouver’s deepest excavation to date, the 133ft deep dig at 1515 Alberni Street
—
From the first bucket with an excavator to the final bucket with a telestick excavator, the final step in deep excavation is craning out the machines so building construction can continue in the vertical direction
—
It’s always pleasure watching the professionals at BelPacific and Kansen work!
Which machine are you stroking a cheque for and adding to the fleet, Volvo’s 950F or Cat’s 395, and why?

Norcon Construction’s D8T working on a coal mine reclamation project sloping coversoil to a ~26 degree slope
--
The reclamation process involves recontouring overburden/spoil piles, followed by placing suitable subsoil (regolith) and then a 30cm thick layer of coversoil for native vegetation species to re-establish
--
There is an incredible amount of work that goes into reclaiming previously mined land to a productive state, something Canadian Mining companies take great pride in!

@kpcldirtmovers 349 with skeleton bucket screening material. It’s effectively a grizzly built into a bucket, sizing fine (dirt/sand) from coarse (cobble rock) material
—
Scoop up a bucket, shake the bucket and material is screened through the openings in the bucket while rock/cobble is retained in the bucket
—
In this particular case, material was being screened on site to create various sizes of rip rap for a nearby dam outflow repair project
